I recently visited Vidhana Soudha and took the guided tour — it was a truly memorable experience! The architecture is absolutely magnificent, reflecting the grandeur of Indian democracy. The guide’s explanation was detailed and very engaging, which made the whole visit even more meaningful. The Speaker’s Gallery was especially awesome — a must-see! I highly recommend this tour to anyone interested in history, politics, or architecture.

This state legislature building is one of Bengaluru’s most iconic landmarks, known for its exquisite handwork, grand architecture, and heritage charm. The intricate details on the facade are a testament to the craftsmanship of a bygone era—truly a treat for history and architecture lovers.

It’s not just a historic site but also an important metro stop, with easy access to the High Court and Cubbon Park. However, the main road outside is extremely busy, and there’s very limited open space in front, so be cautious while visiting—especially if you're on foot or with children.

Despite that, it’s widely considered a must-visit location when in Bangalore. A great place to soak in the civic pride and cultural legacy of the city!

🏛️ Vidhana Soudha – The Pride of Karnataka’s Governance & Grandeur! 🌟🇮🇳

My visit to Vidhana Soudha, one of Bengaluru’s most iconic landmarks, was a powerful reminder of India's architectural brilliance and democratic strength. Whether you're a tourist, photographer, or a proud local, standing in front of this majestic structure fills you with awe and pride. 🙏📸

🏢 Architecture & History
The Vidhana Soudha is the seat of the Karnataka State Legislature and is one of the largest legislative buildings in India. Its architecture is a majestic blend of Dravidian, Rajasthani, and Indo-Saracenic styles.
Every part of this structure — from the massive granite columns to the intricately carved details — showcases the brilliance of Indian craftsmanship. The grandeur of the domes, the towering entrance, and the lush gardens surrounding it make it a visual treat. 🏰🌿

🇮🇳 The building bears the proud inscription: "Government Work is God's Work" — a reminder of the building’s purpose and its role in shaping the lives of millions in Karnataka.

📷 Photography Heaven
Though the building is not open to tourists for internal visits, the outside view is more than enough to impress. The sheer scale, symmetry, and the detailed carvings on this structure are a delight for photography lovers.
As you can see in my photos, the morning sunlight, cloudy skies, or evening lights — every time of the day gives it a unique charm. 📸🌤️🌆

🌳 Surroundings
Vidhana Soudha is surrounded by beautifully maintained lawns, iron fencing, and clean surroundings. Located near Cubbon Park and High Court, it’s in the heart of Bengaluru’s administrative zone. The whole area is ideal for a walking tour, especially early in the morning or late evening. 🌳🚶‍♂️

👮 Security & Access
Due to its political and administrative importance, entry is restricted, and security is tight — which is understandable. You can walk around the perimeter freely and take photos, but getting too close might not be allowed. Make sure to respect the rules and follow security guidelines. 🚫📷

🌇 Best Time to Visit
Early morning or post-sunset are ideal times to visit for the best photos. During evenings, the building is beautifully lit with golden lighting that makes it look like a royal palace. If you’re lucky to visit on Republic Day or Karnataka Rajyotsava, the whole area is decorated and feels even more special. ✨🇮🇳

💭 Final Thoughts
Vidhana Soudha isn’t just a building — it’s a symbol of democracy, power, and pride for Karnataka. Its grand presence makes you feel patriotic and respectful of the governance system. I highly recommend including this site in your Bengaluru itinerary, even if it's just for a peaceful walk and a few great pictures. 🌟📷

I recently visited Vidhana Soudha during the Book Fair Mela and had a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to go inside. It was open to the public for just a few days, and I feel lucky to have experienced it. In the evening, there was an amazing concert by Arjun Janya, which made the visit even more special. The building looks absolutely stunning when it's lit up at night. The area around is clean and green, perfect for a peaceful walk or to take some great photos. If you’re visiting Bengaluru, Vidhana Soudha is definitely a place you shouldn’t miss!

A Glimpse of Grandeur: Visiting Bangalore's Vidhana Soudha

For anyone interested in history, architecture, or a bit of local pride, the Vidhana Soudha is an essential stop in Bangalore. This massive granite building, which houses the state legislature of Karnataka, is more than just a government office—it's an impressive work of art and a powerful symbol of post-independence India.

Built in the 1950s, its architecture is often described as "Neo-Dravidian," a style that beautifully blends traditional South Indian temple elements with modern design. From the richly carved pillars and arches to the immense, sprawling layout, the building commands attention. At the very top, a striking dome sits, crowned with the four-headed national emblem.

The most famous feature, and a must-see for visitors, is the inscription on the front: "Government's Work is God's Work" in both English and Kannada.While you can't go inside the working government building, simply standing in front of it is an experience in itself. The sheer scale is breathtaking.

The best time to visit is in the evening, especially on Sundays and public holidays, when the entire structure is illuminated with thousands of lights. It's a truly spectacular sight that makes you appreciate the city's unique blend of tradition and modernity. Vidhana Soudha stands as a testament to the state's heritage and a true landmark for all of India.

sources.snippet: Amid the lush greenery of Cubbon Park lies the Seshadri Iyer Memorial Hall, built in commemoration of Sir Kumarapuram Seshadri Iyer, the Diwan of Mysore from 1883 to 1901. The European-style building, characterized by its Tuscan columns, was built in 1915. It was commissioned by Lord Curzon, the then Viceroy of India.

placeMetadata.name: Mayo Hall

sources.snippet: Established in 1883 in honor of Lord Mayo (India’s fourth Viceroy), the Mayo Hall is one of the most distinct buildings in the city. With its beautiful neo-classical architecture, complete with Italian chandeliers, Tuscan columns, Greek ledges, elaborate furnishings, and wooden flooring, this two-story building is a sight to behold. Today it houses several government offices on the ground floor and a museum dedicated to the founder of Bangalore on the upper floor.

placeMetadata.name: Tipu Sultan's Summer Palace

sources.snippet: Tipu Sultan (1750-1799) went down in history as a hero, and is known as the Tiger of Mysore. He also had a penchant for grand architecture, reflected in his summer palace, ‘Rash-e-Jannat’ or ‘Envy of the Heavens’. Predominantly constructed using teak wood, Tipu Sultan’s Summer Palace is decorated with meticulous motifs, and is a visual treat.
sources.shortName: A Tour Of Bangalore's Architectural Landmarks

sources.snippet: This exquisite royal palace tops the list of historical places in Bangalore. One of the finest examples of Indo-Islamic architecture in Bangalore, Tipu Sultan’s Summer Palace served as the summer residence of Tipu Sultan, the ruler of the Kingdom of Mysore. Like other Indo-Islamic buildings in different parts of the country, the ceilings and walls of the palace feature beautiful floral patterns and the arches display an intricate design.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Historical Places in Bangalore

sources.snippet: Situated in the center of Old Bangalore, Tipu Sultan’s Summer Palace was first built in 1537 by Kempe Gowda (Bangalore’s founding father) with mud bricks. Later it was modified and rebuilt by Mysore ruler Hyder Ali and finished by his son Tipu Sultan in 1791. It is a two-story palace and is predominantly made of teak.

reviews.reviewText:
Tipu Sultan's Summer Palace in Bangalore is a must-visit destination for history buffs and architecture enthusiasts. This 18th-century palace, built in 1791, served as the summer retreat for Tipu Sultan, the ruler of Mysore. Here's what you can expect:

*Architecture and Features:*

- The palace is a beautiful example of Indo-Islamic architecture, with teak pillars, arches, and balconies.
- The two-storey structure has a stone plinth and wooden beams, with intricate carvings and floral motifs.
- The upper level has an open balcony area with projecting balconies where Tipu Sultan would hold court.

*Things to See and Do:*

- Explore the museum on the ground floor, showcasing Tipu Sultan's belongings, including his clothes, crown, and weapons.
- See the replica of Tipu's tiger, a mechanical tiger that symbolizes his victory over the British.
- Visit the durbar hall on the first floor, where Tipu Sultan would hold court, and admire the Zenana quarters, the private rooms for the royal ladies.
- Take a stroll in the well-manicured gardens and lawns in front of the palace ¹ ².

*Practical Information:*

- *Timings:* 8:30 AM to 5:30 PM, daily
- *Nearest Metro Station:* KR Market Metro Station
- *Getting There:* Take a cab or auto ride, as parking can be a hassle

*Tips:*

- Spend 1-2 hours exploring the palace and its surroundings.
- Consider a guided tour for a more in-depth understanding of the palace's history and architecture.
- Visit the nearby Bangalore Fort and Venkateswara Temple to make the most of your trip

Overall, Tipu Sultan's Summer Palace is a great place to visit if you're interested in history, architecture, or simply want to experience the city's cultural heritage.

Clicking pictures is allowed majorly except in some restricted areas. Walking and climbing stairs, no lift facility available so elders should be mindful of that.
Picturesque Ambience.

I enjoyed exploring the intricate designs and learning about Tipu Sultan’s legacy. Though it’s not a very large place, it’s definitely worth a short visit if you’re interested in history and culture. Overall, a calm and enriching experience in the heart of the city.

As a history enthusiast visiting Bangalore in late August 2025, I decided to explore the Tipu Sultan Summer Palace (also known as Daria Daulat Bagh), a well-preserved relic from the 18th century. Located in the heart of Srirangapatna, just a short 15-20 km drive from central Bangalore, this palace served as the summer retreat of Tipu Sultan, the "Tiger of Mysore," and stands as a testament to his innovative spirit and architectural prowess. Built in 1784, it's one of the few surviving structures from Tipu's era, showcasing Indo-Islamic design with intricate woodwork that immediately captivated me.
Upon arrival, the palace's modest entrance belies the treasures inside. The main building is constructed primarily from teak wood, but what truly stood out was the liberal use of sandalwood in the decorations, carvings, and artifacts on display. Tipu Sultan was known for his fondness for sandalwood – a fragrant, durable wood native to Karnataka – and the palace features beautiful inlaid panels and motifs made from it, adding a luxurious, aromatic touch to the interiors. The museum within houses an impressive collection of Tipu's personal items, including swords, coins, and paintings, many of which incorporate sandalwood elements. One highlight was the ornate wooden cradle and ceremonial objects, all crafted from this precious material, evoking the opulence of the Mysore Kingdom. The scent of aged sandalwood lingers subtly, enhancing the immersive experience.
Wandering through the lush gardens surrounding the palace, I appreciated the serene ambiance – perfect for a half-day visit. The audio guide (available for a small fee) provides fascinating insights into Tipu's battles against the British and his administrative reforms. However, the site can get crowded on weekends, so I recommend visiting early morning. Entry is affordable at around ₹20 for Indians (₹200 for foreigners), and photography is allowed inside.
For anyone interested in sandalwood craftsmanship, this palace is a must-see, as it exemplifies how the wood was used in royal settings. If you're in Bangalore, pair it with a trip to nearby sandalwood-focused spots like the Government Sandalwood Depot or local artisan shops in Srirangapatna, where you can see modern carvings and even purchase small souvenirs made from certified sandalwood. Overall, the Tipu Sultan Summer Palace earns a solid 4.5/5 stars from me – a blend of history, culture, and natural artistry that leaves you inspired. Highly recommended for a culturally enriching outing!..

placeMetadata.name: Shri Gavi Gangadhareshwara Swamy Temple

sources.snippet: Gavipuram Cave Temple, or Gavi Gangadhareshwara Temple, is a mystifying (yet explicable) rock-cut architectural marvel. Built in a natural cave in the 1500s, the Lord Shiva temple houses a monolithic-cut idol of the deity. Every year on the day of Makara Sankranti, the evening sunlight spreads over the intricate monolithic sculptures and illuminates the Shiva linga inside.
sources.shortName: A Tour Of Bangalore's Architectural Landmarks

sources.snippet: In addition to being a prominent religious site for Hindus, Gavi Gangadhareshwara Temple is also one of the most interesting Bangalore historical places. This brilliantly designed ancient cave temple puts on display one of the finest examples of rock-cut architecture in the country. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva, and the study reveals that the history of the temple traces it back to the 9th Century.

In addition, it also has several monolithic sculptures and pillars.

Shri Gavi Gangadhareshwara Swamy Temple, Kempegowda Nagar, Bengaluru is one of the most mystical and ancient temples in the city, steeped in history and divinity. Carved out of natural monolithic rock inside a cave, the temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and holds immense spiritual significance. The moment you step inside, the coolness of the cave and the sacred ambiance instantly evoke a deep sense of peace and reverence.

The temple is particularly famous for a rare astronomical phenomenon where sunlight passes through the temple’s precise architecture and illuminates the Shiva Linga inside the cave on Makar Sankranti. This unique occurrence draws thousands of devotees and tourists alike, highlighting the brilliant blend of devotion and science in ancient Indian temple architecture. The serene environment, echoing chants, and the rock-carved idols leave every visitor awestruck.

A visit is incomplete without receiving the Swamy special prasadam — a humble yet divine offering usually comprising pongal, sweet laddus, and occasionally panaka (jaggery water), especially during festivals. The prasadam is served with devotion, and it's believed to carry the blessings of Lord Gangadhareshwara himself. This temple is not just a place of worship; it is a timeless spiritual marvel in the heart of Bengaluru.
K.vinoth

placeMetadata.name: Government Museum

sources.snippet: Undoubtedly one of the most charming buildings in Bangalore, the Government Museum on Kasturba Road, has been around since 1877. Previously, the city’s museum was part of the Cantonment’s jail building before it moved to this neoclassical structure that was planned by Col. Richard Hieram Sankey. The stunning red building is taken to the next level with its grand Corinthian columns, graceful balconettes topped with pediments, and doors and windows that have been painted in a soothing green.
sources.shortName: Visit This Historical Buildings In The City

sources.snippet: Government Museum is the second oldest museum in South India which showcases exquisite works of art. Government Museum first opened in a rented building in 1865 and later in 1879 construction of the new building designed by Colonel Sankey was completed which became functional in 1980. Explore the galleries of this hub of knowledge which has a wealth of information pertaining to various sections like ethnology, natural history, architecture, sculpture, etc.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Historical Places in Bangalore

sources.snippet: Government Museum | #8 of 10 Best Historical Places in Bangalore. Museums are places where you can get glimpses of history through a variety of objects and artifacts. The Government Museum in Bangalore, however, is not only a treasure trove of geological and archaeological artifacts, but also a historical building in itself.

placeMetadata.description: History museum displaying carvings, archeology & weaponry since 1877 in a historic red building.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Government Museum, located in Bangalore and established in 1865, is one of India's oldest and most popular museums. It attracts over 90,000 visitors annually. The museum features a historic red building and encompasses 18 galleries showcasing a wide array of artifacts including carvings, weaponry, sculptures, textiles, jewelry, coins, inscriptions and paintings dating back to ancient kingdoms such as Tanjore, Deccan and Mysore.
placeMetadata.address: Venkatappa Art Gallery Building, Kasturba Rd, Ambedkar Veedhi, Sampangi Rama Nagar, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560001, India

reviews.reviewText:
An historic landmark of Bangalore, the heritage of Karnataka. It's one of the oldest museum.

The museum have a good collection of artifacts, archeological finds, sculptures, paintings, ancient guns and swords and stone carvings.

There's an entry fees of approx 20rs per person for the entry. And parking facilities are available.

Also there's small snacks shops available near the gate for refreshing.

Government Museum, Bangalore, established in 1865 by the Mysore State with the guidance of Surgeon Edward Balfour who founded the museum in Madras and supported by the Chief Commissioner of Mysore, L.B. Bowring, is one of the oldest museums in India and the second oldest museum in South India. It is now an archaeological museum and has a rare collection of archaeological and geological artifacts including old jewellery, sculpture, coins and inscriptions. The museum is also home to the Halmidi inscription, the earliest Kannada inscription (450 AD).

GOVT MEUSIUM, BANGLORE,KASTURBA ROAD was Under renovation
Photos from newly constructed hebber gallary in the same compoud entry 50 rupees.

The Government Museum in Bangalore showcases breathtaking architecture that leaves a lasting impression. While currently temporarily closed. The exterior alone is a testament to the city's rich cultural heritage, promising a fascinating experience for art and history enthusiasts.

**Government Museum (Venkatappa Art Gallery), Bangalore:**

1. **Artistic Treasure Trove:**
The museum houses a diverse collection of artifacts, sculptures, and paintings. The Venkatappa Art Gallery is particularly known for its impressive display of artworks by K. Venkatappa and other renowned artists. The range of exhibits provides visitors with a comprehensive view of India's artistic heritage.

2. **Venkatappa's Legacy:**
K. Venkatappa, a prominent artist, was instrumental in establishing the art gallery. His works, including landscapes, portraits, and historical paintings, are showcased, offering a glimpse into the evolution of Indian art during the early 20th century.

3. **Sculptures and Artefacts:**
The museum features a notable collection of sculptures, artifacts, and archaeological finds. These exhibits span different periods of Indian history, providing an educational experience for those interested in the country's rich cultural heritage.

4. **Architectural Charm:**
The architecture of the museum adds to the overall experience. The building itself is a historical landmark, contributing to the city's architectural heritage. The design and layout enhance the viewing of artworks and artifacts.

5. **Educational Value:**
The museum serves as an educational resource for schools and art enthusiasts. Regular workshops, guided tours, and lectures contribute to the dissemination of knowledge about art and culture. It is a valuable destination for students and researchers alike.

6. **Temporary Exhibitions:**
The museum often hosts temporary exhibitions, featuring contemporary artworks and thematic displays. These rotating exhibits keep the museum dynamic and offer something new for repeat visitors.

7. **Accessibility and Location:**
Situated in the heart of Bangalore, the museum is easily accessible. Its central location makes it a convenient stop for both locals and tourists exploring the city.

8. **Conservation Efforts:**
Preserving the artworks and maintaining the museum's infrastructure are crucial aspects. Adequate conservation efforts ensure that the exhibits remain in good condition for future generations to appreciate.

9. **Cafeteria and Amenities:**
Some museums include amenities like cafeterias or gift shops. These facilities can enhance the overall visitor experience by providing a place to relax and reflect on the exhibits.

10. **Visitor Experience:**
The overall visitor experience depends on personal interests, but those passionate about art, history, and culture often find the Government Museum (Venkatappa Art Gallery) in Bangalore to be a rewarding destination.

It's a great place, there are two museums next to each other, the science and historic museum. This is the historic one.
The entry fee is ₹20 for adults and ₹10 for kids as on Feb 2021 and there is ample parking space.
It was a nice time to see so many ancient things, the sulptures and paintings etc. It's a must visit place if you enjoy historical museums.

Impressive quaint red heritage building on Kasturba Road more than 150 years old. If you love art, history  and heritage this is a must visit. With the Rs 20 entry ticket one can also visit the art collection having amongst others some find Ten more paintings and wooden sculptures at Venkatappa Art gallery which is in the same premises and one leads to another. Archaeological findings comprising of pottery, sculptures, armaments, coins and scriptures dating back to Neolithic age can be found at the museum. Some amazing sculptures of prehistoric times well preserved makes it a must visit when coming to Bangalore for a visit. Good for children too to make them aware of our rich history and culture. Open from 10 am to 5 pm

Government Musem, Bengaluru, Karnataka is the Official Government Museum which is situated adjacent to Visvesvaraya industrial and technological museum in Bengaluru. This museum is established in 1865 and now this museum is one of the most oldest museums which are still operating in India and second most oldest museum in South India.
In 1877, the New building was constructed and Opened.
From that time, that same building is still operating as one of the most finest archaeological museums in India.
It is now an archaeological museum and has a rare collection of archaeological and geological artifacts including old jewellery, sculpture, coins and inscriptions. The museum is also home to the Halmidi inscription,the earliest Kannada inscription (450 AD).
As this museum is almost in the City centre and very near to Visvesvaraya museum and many other main attractions of the Cit, the annual visitors will cross 1 Lakh in Number from Various parts of the Country and even from other Countries also.
This museum is very rich in showcasing our culture heritage and history via its preserved items as they are the remaining evidences of our History.
So if you are planning a trip to Bengaluru, please visit this Government Museum also.

placeMetadata.name: National Gallery of Modern Art (Bengaluru)

sources.snippet: With its impressive collection of paintings, sculptures and prints across different periods, the NGMA in Bangalore is a popular spot for art and culture enthusiasts in the ooru. However, if you’re someone who appreciates architecture, the structure has much for you to admire as well. When the 100-year-old Manikyavelu mansion was converted into the art gallery, the team at INTACH (the folks behind the refurbishing project) wanted to ensure it brought together the heritage of the structure and the modern elements of an art space.
sources.shortName: Architectural Marvels Of Bangalore - Best Architectural Buildings of Bangalore

sources.snippet: National Gallery of Modern Art Bangalore inaugurated in 2009 houses more than 14000 implausible works of art from various famous artists like Rabindranath Tagore, Jamini Roy, Raja Ravi Verma and many more. It is a perfect blend of art dating back to the 18th Century to a modern piece of work which showcases the cultural roots of India with passing time through many variations. This gallery also hosts many workshops, educational tours, seminars, talks all related to art and culture which represents India.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Historical Places in Bangalore

placeMetadata.description: Museum housing paintings by modern & contemporary Indian artists, plus a cafe & an auditorium.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The National Gallery of Modern Arts (Bengaluru) is a sprawling museum established in 2009 within the heritage Manikyavelu Mansions. It is part of a trio of galleries set up by the Indian Ministry of Culture to showcase the historical significance and heritage of Indian art dating back to the 18th century.
placeMetadata.address: Manikyavelu Mansion, GF, 49, Palace Rd, Vasanth Nagar, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560052, India

reviews.reviewText:
Visited on a weekend and found the place peaceful and inspiring. The entry fee was just Rs.20 with no waiting time. Each artwork tells a unique story and details about the artists are provided beside every piece.

I especially loved the Braille section, such a beautiful and inclusive idea. Photography of the artwork and interiors is allowed though personal photos inside the gallery are not permitted. There's a lovely outdoor space for pictures and a cozy café to unwind.

Highly recommended for anyone looking for a calm, enriching day out in Bangalore.

A well maintained National museum located in prime area of the city.
Visited on a weekend entry fee was 20 rs only.
The place is peaceful with lush greenary. There is a variety of paintings and artwork. The paintings reflect various situations and themes that are on based, society, culture, history etc.
Overall I liked the experience and would recommend art lovers to visit

Tucked right in the middle of the city, yet far away from all its chaos, this place is pure calm. The lush trees, shrubs, and blooming flowers make you feel like you’ve stepped into a little oasis. The entry fee for Indians is just ₹20 – a small price for the peace and beauty you’ll find here.

Once inside, you’ll be asked to leave your bags at the store near the entrance and collect a token. The main art gallery sits in a charming old building that itself feels like a piece of history. The ground floor is home to the incredible works of the legendary Nandalal Bose, while the upper floors are filled with artworks that truly stop you in your tracks – acrylics, watercolours, oils, mixed media, ink, and pencil sketches, all beautifully displayed.

The building’s design, its thoughtful upkeep, and the warm politeness of the staff deserve a special mention. Practical touches like the lift, auditorium, washrooms, and a small cafeteria on the ground floor make the visit even smoother.

The place is good with displays of art. The ticket costs Rs. 20 for Indians, there was no rush. There is a cafe , souvenir shop (both of them offer reasonable price for everything) as well as an art archive above the cafeteria. Personal photographs are not allowed, though you can take photos of the gallery. The security guards were not really welcoming, they kept on following us everywhere, which felt a bit intimidating

Really nice gallery, the art was wonderful and the space and area itself were quite peaceful. However, I didn’t quite understand the rules around not being allowed to take videos of the place/pictures of yourself next to the art. Respected it regardless, of course, but the constant presence of staff in each room, closely watching and following visitors, made the experience a bit uncomfortable. I get that they’re there to ensure the rules are followed, but the way it was handled felt a little intrusive.

First visit, and I was honestly surprised. 20rs ticket, and what you get is priceless. Beautiful old building, peaceful garden, and rooms filled with art I’ve never seen before. Felt calm and curious the whole time. It’s not crowded or loud just quiet, thoughtful, and very different from usual places in Bangalore.

A perfect place to slow down and see something new.

Entry fee is just Rs. 20 for Indians. Every room has security personnel that are doing their job diligently, at times it feels like they are stalking you 😅 but they are super friendly and helpful. However, if you have any doubts, there's no one for clarification. I was told that guided tours are conducted on Wednesdays and Saturdays at 4 pm (please call the museum to confirm). Art is subjective, so cannot comment on it. I just want to point out that visit this museum with an open mind, not just by the name of the museum. There were paintings and sculptures (wooden, metal, stone, etc.). While it's kept well in terms of cleanliness and organization, there's lingering foul smell in the hall on the first floor. There's a gift shop, with the items reasonably priced. Behind that you could find the canteen (by the looks of it and the menu, I only purchased a water bottle). And beside the canteen, drinking water and bathrooms (not-so-clean) are available. Art library can be accessed from the adjacent staircase. I spent around 90 minutes, time well spent.

Such a calm and serene place. One can spend ample of time here peacefully in weekend. They have artifacts getting changed once in every 3months. Security is tight and restrictions are high. Not at all allowed to capture photos for most of the arts,  and not even selfies or photos are allowed to click in the building.
In the same premises, in the side by block, we have small cafeteria, washrooms. Cafeteria has an open outdoor sitting with a very natural view of trees. I just felt like eating by sitting in my balcony. Library is also available. Whole place is just 💚

reviews.reviewText:

The natural light and neutral colors made the home feel open and airy. Each room offers a sense of spaciousness and clarity, allowing the beauty of simplicity to shine through. This thoughtful design not only looks great but also provides a soothing retreat to us.

Ashwin sir has helped us understand the fundamental needs of our home, leading us in its planning process. In every meeting, Ashwin sir's insights have helped us simplify and refine our thoughts.

Anshul sir has offered essential guidance on prioritizing our investments, aligning them with our aspirations for the fulfillment of our home.

Prabhu and Sneha have been consistently delivering the essential technical specifications to keep our project moving forward smoothly.

I deeply appreciate the contributions made by Ashwin Architects and the entire team. Their dedication, creativity, and attention to each detail were truly exceptional. They have understood our vision and supported us in making the right decisions.

----- "With every touch, a touch of art,
RAMANEEYAM dwells in every part."-------

Ashwin sir and team are very professional and delivered our dream home beyond our imagination!
Anshul sir was our main point of contact and he always ensured things were running smoothly and in a timely manner. The team was always available for all our questions and made sure we got clarity on things when we needed it.

Good day light and open spaces were something we appreciate in our home and this was the brief we gave the team. They designed double height walls with skylight which we absolutely love in our space! The layout to construction to finishing to furniture & landscaping was coordinated by Ashwin Architects; honestly the process was not a piece of cake but building a home doesn't come without hurdles along the way! But, Ashwin Architects helped us navigate through all of the challenges in a professional manner!

We are forever indebted to the team.

Regards,
Shruthi

“It’s not how big a house is, it’s how happy the home is”

After careful consideration we met Mr. Ashwin and shared our thoughts around how we would envisage ‘Out Nest’, where we spend our future.

Mr. Ashwin and his team delivered extraordinarily high-quality work. They were disciplined, thoughtful, and insightful. They offered creative solutions and ensured accountability to deadlines and milestones. As they demonstrated their excellence and ensured our dream is met.

Without saying, his team includes Ms. Hema and Mr. Bharath who made us comfortable in every step and partnered and always reachable on phone/in person for any clarification. Timely site visit and coordination with contractors ensure smooth implementation according to design and plan.

Ashwin and his team goes beyond the call of duty - Probably this is a WOW factor in them which strengthen the client relationship. It took 2 years to complete the project, but we must agree that every detail in the design has made our house stand tall. Once Ashwin mentioned in our meeting and I quote - “ He would like to design our home, which doesn’t require any changes for next two decades”. We were able to correlate his words once we moved. Any guest who walks-in to our home will drop their jaws and tell us that we have a good taste for the architecture :-) - Truth is this is designed by the one of the best Architect team in Bangalore.

We are sure, like us many would be dreaming of one such home and they can be rest assured giving the project to Mr. Ashwin will not disappoint.

Our home - “Duhitha” pictures well tell the rest of the story.

We are thankful for Mr. Ashwin and his team for this beautiful house. We wish them all the best for their upcoming project.

Arjun & Family

We learnt about Ashwin architects by looking at their videos on YouTube. Our search for an architect ended at our very first meeting with Ashwin and Anshul.

I was very skeptical that the vision of my home would get lost in communication between us and all the parties involved. But Ashwin and teams delivery exceeded our imagination in every way. The team not only wore architects hat, but several others. They kept a keen eye on the civil work and all of the interior. Sofas, curtains, woodwork and landscapes - all were carefully designed to make the whole house look very aesthetically pleasing.

Ashwin and Anshul bring in immense experience to the game. Their design was focused on building a fully functional house. There’s deep thought behind every single inch of space. They’re with you at every step of the process. They educate you about where to spend and more importantly where not to.

All in all, it worked out great for us and I highly recommend Ashwin and Team.

Building a house is a once in a lifetime experience. Ashwin sir and Anshul enabled this experience for us.
Every customer has a design / expectation in their mind. The true value and satisfaction for us was in the highly interactive approach that Anshul adopted. While he would come up with initial designs based on our inputs, he constantly incorporated suggestions and Co-created the design.
The end result has been a great combination of a modern design with elements of traditional design built in.
We now have a few unique design features which have become reference for people in Nisarga Layout.
We are happy to have chosen to work with Ashwin Architects and Anshul. We now have a heavenly house named Anugraha, in a Layout that is aptly called Nisarga Layout.

It was once in a lifetime experience with Ashwin Architects. We made a good decision by choosing Ashwin Architects to plan our home. They listen to your requirements carefully and they plan accordingly. They coordinate with your Engineer and make sure that your home is built with perfectionism. They prefer quality work. We are totally happy and satisfied with Mr. Ashwin and his team.

We wanted to build a well-ventilated home as far as possible, close to nature. It was challenging to find an architect who understood our needs and be with us on our journey with the same passion, have patience, and professionalism.

At our first meeting with Ashwin, we were happy with the detailed discussion and knew we had made the right choice.

The first design we got was perfect, very well balanced in terms of functionality and contemporary looks that would fit into our budget.

Every detail was well thought of, thoroughly discussed, and put to paper before it was executed. The architect team was with us right from choosing all the vendors, procurement, and quality checks during the entire construction.

We are delighted with the excellent output. Thank you Ashwin, Hema & Anshul, for all your efforts.

Thanking the entire team of Ashwin Architects for the completion of our beautiful home. All our requirements of a 5bhk Modern house on 40x60 plot, yet, spacious, elegant, Fully equipped home with ample space for landscaping were fulfilled & definitely surpassed our expectations.
The house was efficiently designed with natural lighting & ventilation and also comes equipped with all the energy saving technologies.
All the phases of construction right from planning, designing, coordination, Interior design and until the right finish quality were very well managed.
We would definitely look forward for any future projects with you.

placeMetadata.name: Bengaluru Palace

sources.snippet: Elaborate towers, embellished doorways, floral motifs and lacquer-ware makes Bangalore Palace a sight to behold. When Chamarajendra Wadiyar X’s British guardians bought land from educationist Rev. J. Garrett, they were looking to build an unassuming accommodation for the young Maharaja. Four years later, in 1878, a Tudor style palace emerged, which still has the ability to leave visitors wonderstruck.
sources.shortName: A Tour Of Bangalore's Architectural Landmarks

sources.snippet: With its turrets and towers, the iconic Bangalore Palace looks more like an English castle than a Maharaja's residence. Often described as a mini-version of Windsor Castle, the stately palace features Tudor Revival architecture with rising towers and turrets adding to the look. Apart from interesting exhibits, the interior decor includes everything from stained glass windows and old paintings to floral motifs and wood carvings.
sources.shortName: Architectural Marvels Of Bangalore - Best Architectural Buildings of Bangalore

placeMetadata.description: Modern royal palace modeled on Windsor Castle offering tours, outdoor concerts & an amusement park.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Bangalore Palace, situated in Malleshwaram just 3 km from the city center, is a majestic royal palace renowned for its stunning architecture and intricate carvings. With an entry fee of 260rs for Indians and 500rs for NRIs, this historical gem boasts 35 rooms and an open courtyard on the ground floor adorned with granite seats embellished with fluorescent blue ceramic tiles.
placeMetadata.address: Bengaluru, Karnataka, India

reviews.reviewText: The Bengaluru Palace is a real palace where the kings of the  Wadior dynasty lived. It has an entry fee of ₹270 per head for Indian visitors. It has a huge collection of photographs of the last few kings and queens of the dynasty. They give a free audio guide - a device with headset to listen to the history in every spot of the palace. They have maintained very neatly. Photography and videography are prohibited. One can witness the photo collection, artefacts collection, paintings of significant painters like Raja Ravi varma. Immerse oneself into the rich history and culture of mysore kingdom. Outside the palace a neatly maintained garden is there. There one can click wonderful photos keeping the palace in the backdrop. The place is peaceful, surrounded by trees. Many families, couples, friends and tourists visit this palace daily. If you are in Bengaluru, this palace is a must visit place.

Famous attraction in Bangalore known for it's exterior grandeur and beautifully arranged lawns and gardens. The interior is not worthwhile,only some average courtyard and rooms of the royal family. Exterior is beautiful and well maintained. Entry fee is 270 rupees which is high.

Felt like I was walking inside an old royal house. The building looks grand from outside, good for photos. Inside, it’s quiet and old-style, with old furniture, paintings, and halls.

Ticket was rs 270, bit costly for what you see, but okay for a one-time visit. Best part was just sitting outside and enjoying the view.

Visited Bengaluru Palace today and had a good experience. The palace is truly majestic, and I especially loved the beautifully maintained garden – perfect for photography. The pleasant weather made the visit even more enjoyable. A must-visit place in Bangalore!

If you are new to Bangalore and want to have a local outing then it's a one time visit.The structure of palace is fascinating from outside.They charge 300/- for Indians and 500/- for foreigners and give an audio device to listen.Not that worth it as compared to Mysore palace so far the entry fee is concerned.Historical lovers would like this place. Cameras and photography are strictly prohibited inside the palace.

Just seeing and listening to the history felt the old king rules and lifestyle.

Honest feedback - If you are interested in history then do visit as it has lots of handmade painting and foreign materials across palace.

Walking through Bangalore Palace felt like stepping into a fairytale. The majestic towers, stunning woodwork, and peaceful gardens left me in awe. Built in 1878, its charm and rich royal history make this place truly special. It's a beautiful window into Bangalore’s unique heritage and I absolutely loved my visit! Highly suggested place

> Beautiful and majestic historical palace.

> Stunning architecture with intricate carvings and designs.

> Well-maintained interiors and gardens.

> Audio guide and signboards available for easy understanding.

> Photography allowed only outside the palace.

> Entry fee high Rs .270.

> Best time to visit is in the evening.

Clean surroundings and good security.

reviews.reviewText:
Our apartment in Bengaluru was remodeled by Kamat and Rozario. Saying 'remodeled' is an understatement because the house feels and looks out of the world. Mr. Lester was involved from day 1. We were always of the view that 'form follows the function' giving more importance to usability and maintenance while keeping the aesthetics in mind. We were very impressed when the team showed us the design and we were eager to start the work.

Their contractor Mr Satish Sharma has an excellent team. They were very particular about process they followed and their workmanship was superb. This house is in single tower high-rise building, which has its own challenges in terms of material movements, noise and dust. However the team took a great care of all these aspects and I never had any complaint from the neighbors or association. We had to relook into few aspects of design during the execution and team was very willing to make the changes and accept our suggestions.

At the end of the project the house was transformed into a totally a different house. Our guests always in awe and wonder if this apartment is really part of this building. Thank you Lester and team. Your approach to the work is very professional and customer centric. We are very much delighted!

Kamat & Rozario Architecture is a multi-disciplinary design studio based in Bangalore, India. They offer services in architecture, interior design, and furniture design. The firm has won several awards and has been featured in various publications. They have completed six projects, including residential and educational architecture, as well as interior design. Kamat & Rozario Architecture is considered one of the best architects in Bangalore.

Some of their notable projects include:
#Corbel House

#Stirred Creative

Lester Rozario is a amazing person. Takes the client brief  seriously. Gives patient hearing and open to suggestion. He has conceptualised and ensured a dream home for us. It didn't end there. He accompanied us  to various nurseries and helped us to select the appropriate plants. I recommend Lester & Smruti to those who want personalised abodes no matter what the constraint is.

Kamat & Rozario designed our home and did its interior as well. After our association of more than two years, I have only wonderful things to say about the firm.

The team's creativity, attention to details and commitment to the project has been commendable. They have unmatched willingness to work with us every step of the way to make our home beautiful and comfortable.

If we ever decide to construct another home, it will again be with Kamat & Rozario. Thank you for making it a memorable experience...

This is a late post! But better late than never! 😊 it has been more than a year since we have been living in our dream home! We would like to take this opportunity to express our gratitude to Lester and team for designing and building such a beautiful house for us which we now call our home! They have exceeded our expectations of our dream home in every possible way be it the architectural design, the build quality and the amazing studio-finish interiors. Glad we found them and selected them to design and build our lovely home which we proudly call ‘VANA’ and as they call it ‘Big - Little House’😊

Satish & Shubha

The first time we met Mr.Lester Rozario, Chief architect of Kamat and Rozario architecture, this gentleman patiently listened to all our requirements and noted down all the specifics for the project.  After a couple of rounds of discussion and on liking their approach towards planning and designing we decided to go ahead with them. That perhaps, is one of the best decision we had ever taken, enabling us to write our experience with them from the comfort of new beautiful home. Throughout our journey with them for more than year, these people have always exhibited a thorough professionalism and their passion for architecture. Mr. Lester Rozario and his team of young architects literally hand held us throughout the project and offered valuable suggestions at every point, without interfering with our individual decision. Without them our dream home would have remained only dream. A special thanks to Lester and project architects Mrigank, Sinan and Taniyat. We thank this young team of honest and passionate professionals and wish them all success.

Kamat & Rozario Architecture is a great team to work with especially Lester & Smruti. This Architect couple understand your need better and deliver on expectations. They had the experience, professionalism and enthusiasm that we were looking for.

Lester and Smruti designed my children's house in Bangalore.  Initially, we did not know  them. So, we decided to trace their track record. We saw the houses they had built. The feature in "50 Beautiful Houses In India" of our house is a proof of their architectural talents.

We have great pleasure in wishing them a bright future.

Thomas V. A.

reviews.reviewText:
St. Mary's Basilica, located in the heart of Shivajinagar, Bengaluru, is the oldest church in the city and holds the distinction of being the only church in Karnataka elevated to the status of a minor basilica.  Its origins trace back to the 17th century when Tamil Christian migrants from Gingee settled in the area and built a thatched chapel known as the "Chapel of Kanikkai Madha."  Over the centuries, the church underwent several transformations, culminating in its consecration in 1882.  In 1973, it was granted the status of a minor basilica by Pope Paul VI, making it the sixth church in India to receive this honor  .

Mass Timings:
St. Mary's Basilica offers daily Masses in multiple languages, catering to the diverse congregation.  Masses are conducted in English, Tamil, Kannada, Konkani, and Malayalam at various times throughout the week.  The basilica also observes special services such as the Divine Mercy Prayer daily at 3:00 PM and Holy Hours on the first Friday of every month from 7:00 PM to 8:00 PM  .

Annual Feast:
The basilica is renowned for the St. Mary's Feast, celebrated annually in September.  The festivities commence with a nine-day Novena from August 30th to September 7th, culminating in the grand feast on September 8th, commemorating the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary.  The celebrations include processions, special Masses, and cultural events, drawing thousands of devotees from across the region  .

Visiting Information:
Location: Msgr. F. Noronha Road, Shivajinagar, Bengaluru – 560 051

Visiting Hours: The basilica is open daily from early morning until evening.

Accessibility: Easily accessible via public transportation, with the Shivajinagar Bus Terminus nearby and Cubbon Park Metro Station within close proximity

Nestled in the heart of Shivajinagar, St. Mary’s Basilica is one of the most peaceful and spiritually uplifting places in Bengaluru. As one of the oldest churches in the city, it holds a deep historical and cultural significance, drawing both the faithful and curious visitors alike.

The Neo-Gothic architecture is striking—tall spires, intricate stained-glass windows, and pointed arches that instantly transport you to another era. The central statue of Mother Mary, seen in the image beautifully adorned in traditional Indian-style robes, radiates grace and serenity. This fusion of local devotion and European design gives the basilica a unique charm.

Despite being located in a bustling area, the church complex remains remarkably peaceful, offering a sacred escape from the noise of the city. The atmosphere is calm and reverent, especially during evening services or quiet weekday visits. You can sit in silence, light a candle, or simply take in the sense of holiness that surrounds the space.

The annual St. Mary’s Feast in September is a major event, drawing thousands for its vibrant celebrations, but on regular days, the church maintains its gentle, spiritual aura.

Whether you're religious or not, St. Mary’s Basilica is a must-visit for its historical richness, stunning architecture, and the profound sense of peace it offers.

St. Mary’s Basilica is truly a serene and spiritual place in the heart of Bengaluru. The architecture is breathtaking with its beautiful stained-glass windows and tall spires that give it a peaceful charm. Inside, the atmosphere is calm and prayerful, offering a perfect space for reflection. The church is also well-maintained, and the annual St. Mary’s Feast in September is a sight to experience with its vibrant decorations and devotion. Whether you’re visiting for faith, history, or just some quiet time, this Basilica is definitely worth a visit.

The Someshwara Swamy Temple in Bangalore is a beautiful blend of spiritual serenity and rich history. Located in Halasuru (Ulsoor), it is one of the oldest temples in the city, dating back to the Chola period. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is an excellent example of Dravidian architecture.

As you enter the temple premises, you're greeted by intricately carved pillars, detailed sculptures, and a peaceful ambiance that immediately calms the mind. The gopuram (entrance tower) is a visual treat, decorated with colorful idols and traditional motifs. Inside, the sanctum houses the Shiva lingam, where devotees can offer prayers and experience a deep sense of devotion.

The temple is well-maintained, and the priests are approachable and helpful. It's not overly crowded on regular days, making it a perfect spot for quiet reflection. During festivals like Maha Shivaratri, the temple comes alive with lights, music, and hundreds of devotees.

Whether you're a devotee, a history lover, or someone seeking a peaceful place in the heart of the city, Someshwara Swamy Temple is a must-visit. It’s a timeless spiritual gem amidst the modern bustle of Bangalore.

Nestled in the heart of Halasuru, Bengaluru Sri Someshwara Swamy Temple is a revered Shiva temple believed to be over 1500 years old, with its present structure attributed to the 13th-century Chola rulers. Though inscriptions or historical documents are absent, strong oral traditions preserve its sanctity and history.

According to legend, Sri Jayappa Gowda, the King of Yelahanka, once rested here during a hunting expedition. In a dream, Lord Someshwara revealed his presence within an anthill and recounted how he was once worshipped by the sage Mandavya Muni. Distressed by the decline in devotion, unity, and dharma, the Lord urged the king to build a temple at the site. He obliged, and the idol of Sri Someshwara Swamy was installed and consecrated.

The deity is known to bless devotees with marital harmony, progeny, and relief from afflictions like Apamrityu Dosha and Janma-Mrityu Dosha. Rituals such as Mahabhisheka, Rudrabhisheka, and Panchamruthabhisheka are integral to the temple’s spiritual calendar.

Regular Mahabhisheka and Mahamangalarathi are conducted every Monday. Festivals such as Pradosha, Maha Shivaratri, Karthika Masa Puja, Shiva Deepotsava, Brahmotsava, and Pallaki Utsava draw large gatherings. Particularly during Karthika Masa and Magha Masa, devotees seek blessings through Deeparadhane, believed to bring auspicious outcomes.

The temple architecture features stone pillars with intricate carvings of deities like Ganesha, Vishnu, and Shiva. While a sacred pond exists within the corridor, devotees are not permitted to use it. Offerings of lemon and coconut placed near the Lord are later distributed as prasadam.

Despite the lack of renovation records by kings or Palegars, the temple continues to be a beacon of unwavering faith, spiritual legacy, and community devotion.

The temple is managed by the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments (HRCE), Govt. of Karnataka, and it is well maintained. There's a designated counter for booking poojas and archana tickets, which is convenient for devotees looking for a more involved ritual experience.

The temple complex is home to multiple shrines of Lord Someshwara (Shiva) – the presiding deity, Maa Kaamakshi, Lord Ganesha, Subrahmanya (Kartikeya), Navagrahas, Kaalbhairav, Hanuman, Omkareshwar, Arunachaleshwar, Dakshinamurthy, Lord Vishnu, Brahma, Chandikeshwara and several others.

The mantapam (pillared hall) is a special space—don’t forget to sit and meditate here. The silence, energy, and timeless ambience make it a truly surreal experience, offering rare mental stillness in a bustling city.

Things to note:

- Parking is tight and difficult due to the temple’s location in a densely packed urban area. Best to use public transport or park near Halasuru metro station and walk down.

- A free footwear stand is available near the entrance.

- Mornings are generally quieter and more conducive for darshan and meditation.

- Cleanliness and overall administration are commendable.

So we went for the ‘Movie night under the stars’ in Courtyard. The ambience and set up is good- the concept and them is good too. However the event as such wasn’t to the expectation. We were given headphones to watch the movie, however there were some external noises, the set up was not exclusively for the event, they had the bar open for others beside the event which was a distraction in a way. The projector or the picture quality was also compromised. 3 course meals were served but I feel they could have given better options to chose the food to our palate. We have also been here to attend some pop up events in the conservatory. It is a beautiful place with a great ambiance.  Both the times, we got to taste some really unique and good food.  I enjoy their curation and I wish they have more such pop up events with vegan options.

My only concern is the 100 rupee charge for valet parking.  Given that the events are all priced, this can be exempted and can be made a part of the pricing.

The World Trade Center in Bangalore is a truly unique place, standing tall as a symbol of modern architecture and sophistication. Located in the bustling area of Malleswaram, it offers a world-class environment, making it a prime destination for both businesses and visitors alike.

The towering structure, with its sleek design and high-end facilities, sets a standard for corporate spaces in Bangalore. As soon as you step in, you're greeted by an ambiance of luxury and professionalism, which immediately makes an impression. The quality of infrastructure is top-notch, with state-of-the-art amenities catering to various needs – from global business operations to dining and entertainment.

One of the major highlights of the World Trade Center is its proximity to the Orion Mall, which provides a great mix of shopping, dining, and leisure activities. The location is well-connected, making it convenient for professionals and visitors to commute.

The rich environment here is not just in terms of its luxurious surroundings but also in the diverse community of international and national organizations it houses. Whether you're visiting for business or leisure, the World Trade Center Bangalore offers an experience of quality and class. Highly recommended!

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Indian Institute of Management (IIM) Bangalore is a prestigious business school located in the heart of Bangalore, India. reviews.reviewText:
I had the opportunity to visit IIMB campus for a guided tour by one of its architects Mr Bijoy as part of Bengaluru Hubba.
IIMB celebrated 50 years in 2023. It was established in 1973 in a rented premises. Construction of current campus building started in 1978. Chief architect Dr Balakrishna V Doshi designed and planned it so beautifully. Local granite stone was used to construct the building. He chose the building at the highest point of the 100 acre area and made multiple level drainage system which ensured smooth flow of rainwater without flooding. Mr Doshi was highly inspired by the temples of Tamil Nadu like Madurai Meenakshi temple and Thanjavur Brihadeeshwara temple which have large corridors and pillars. Same has been implemented in IIMB.
IIMB campus building is spacious and well ventilated with many open spaces to get natural light. The campus which now looks like built amidst forest was having just 4 trees when it started. IIMB took assistance of horticultural dept to add greenery and it’s now filled with beautiful plants, large trees and plenty of birds. Gardener Mayanna developed and maintains the greenery in the campus. He is working here from 40 years and was called back after retirement for his exceptional work.
IIMB also has a souvenir shop where you can buy t shirts jackets and other stationeries with IIMB logo.

It’s a wonderful campus everyone dreams to study. Make the best use of it. I wish I get an opportunity to study here.
“Let our study be enlightening”

I had an incredible experience at the Indian Institute of Management Bengaluru while attending Unmaad 2025!
The campus is stunning, with modern facilities and a vibrant atmosphere. The events were well-organized, showcasing amazing talent from various teams. The interaction with students and faculty was enlightening, and I truly appreciated the warm hospitality. Unmaad was not just an event, it was a celebration of creativity and innovation. Highly recommend visiting IIMB for anyone interested in the dynamic world of management!

The Indian Institute of Management, Bangalore, is renowned for its impressive architecture and sustainable design. The campus is beautifully constructed, with each brick uniquely placed to create a harmonious blend with nature. It stands as a significant landmark in India, reflecting the importance of educational excellence and innovation.

IIM Bangalore is more than just an institute,it's an experience. The lush green campus, iconic stone architecture, and serene environment create the perfect setting for learning and reflection. The academic atmosphere, knowledgeable faculty, and engaging discussions leave a lasting impression. A must-visit for anyone passionate about management and education.

IIM Bengaluru is undoubtedly one of the finest business schools in India, known for its exceptional quality of education and world-class faculty. The rigorous academic curriculum is designed to foster critical thinking, leadership, and innovative problem-solving skills, which are essential for thriving in today's global business environment. The institute offers a wide range of courses that cater to various specializations, ensuring a holistic approach to management education.

The campus life at IIMB is vibrant and dynamic, with a perfect blend of academics and extracurricular activities. The lush, green campus is not only architecturally stunning but also provides a serene environment for learning and personal growth. The student community is diverse, talented, and collaborative, which creates an enriching experience both inside and outside the classroom. With numerous clubs, events, and guest lectures, students have ample opportunities to explore their interests, network with industry leaders, and build lasting relationships.

IIMB’s commitment to excellence is evident in its strong alumni network and its reputation for producing top-notch leaders across various sectors.

An architectural cornerstone, looking part it's chequered history. I'm glad this set a precedence of good Indian post independence architecture. Always a delight to visit and always annoying to be part of a tour group as they never give you enough time to sit and experience the visit.

With a beautiful campus and great facilities, including very fine professors, IIMB boasts of a great national significance in management education. It's ranked #2 in India for its flagship PGP course. I believe the institute could reach greater global recognition and attract genius (not only smart) minds by embracing some flexibility - considering students to be adults, future leaders and decision makers, being more transparent in their operations and overall relaxing the norms within the premises. Overall, a vibrant community and a green campus!

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled just 3.5 km from the bustling Bangalore City Railway Station, Vidhan Soudha stands as a magnificent testament to Karnataka's legislative power and architectural prowess. Located on Dr. Ambedkar Road at the northern edge of Cubbon Park, this iconic structure is not only the largest legislative building in India but also a must-visit for anyone exploring Bangalore.
placeMetadata.address: Cuban park legislative assembly, KG Halli, D' Souza Layout, Ashok Nagar, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560001, India

reviews.reviewText:
Vidhan Soudha, located in Bangalore, serves as the seat of the Karnataka State Legislature and is a prominent example of neo-Dravidian architecture. Completed in 1956, this grand building symbolizes the legislative sovereignty of the people of Karnataka, reflecting a design that merges traditional Indian architectural styles with modern materials like granite, steel, and glass.
Architecturally, Vidhan Soudha is striking, characterized by its massive dimensions of 700 feet in length and 350 feet in width. It features a central wing that stands 112 feet tall and houses the Legislative Assembly Chamber. The entrance is marked by a grand staircase with 45 steps, leading to a foyer that offers access to the Assembly Chamber
The building's construction involved over 6,000 workers, including many artisans who contributed to its artistic details, utilizing granite sourced from nearby quarries.
Visitors often admire not only the external grandeur but also the historical significance of the structure, as it stands as a testament to the political evolution of Karnataka. The adjacent Attara Kacheri, which houses the Karnataka High Court, complements the architectural ensemble of this area, showcasing a blend of Gothic and Indo-Saracenic styles

Vidhan Soudha stands as a magnificent symbol of governance, housing the Legislative Assembly. Its stunning architecture draws visitors eager to explore the vibrant atmosphere that surrounds this iconic landmark. As people stroll around its grand exterior, they can't help but feel the rich history and energy that pulses through the area, making it a must-visit destination.

Vidhan Soudha is a truly impressive place. While its exterior is accessible to all, not everyone gets the chance to explore its interior. The architecture is captivating, and the historical significance adds to its allure. A visit is recommended for those interested in the cultural and architectural heritage, even if only to appreciate the exterior grandeur.

Vidhana Soudha is indeed a significant tourist spot in Bangalore, India.It is well known for its impressive architecture, which combines elements of Dravidian and Indo-Saracenic styles.The building is particularly beautiful when illuminated at night.Additionally, Cubbon Park and other attractions are nearby, making it a worthwhile stop for tourists interested in architecture and history.

sources.snippet: The Queen Regent, Kempananjammani, of the Mysore State laid the foundation stone for the hospital in 1897. This was to mark the occasion of Queen Victoria’s 60-year reign. Lord Curzon, the Viceroy of India, inaugurated the completed 140-bed hospital in 1900.
sources.shortName: Visit This Historical Buildings In The City

placeMetadata.address: Mysore Rd, near City Market, New Tharagupet, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560002, India

reviews.reviewText: Good and well maintained hospital with minimal Price

Victoria Hospital is one of the oldest and famous government sector hospital that comes under BMCRI. BMCRI is the epicenter to cure every disease at a very minimal price.

Here the service is very price friendly and the facilities here are very good if you know someone in the hospital itself means it's a cake walk for you. Yes, the services provided here are hard to get outside at this price which is the reason it is usually full of people.
It is very crowded all the time.

As you are seeking for the consultation:
1. Go straight to OPD ( Out Patient Department). The first thing you need to do is to get an OPD card/book without this card or book you cannot do anything in this hospital. There is a particular section at the right corner of the entrance where you can be only rece registration book from OPD.
To get Take the OPD card  you need the patient Aadhar card with you alongside some cash to register and get a registration booklet.

Here everything is free for checkup I was there for my mother hernia operation where I was directed to general surgeon and after that he told me to make a file again to make a file

We need to come to ground floor of OPD and at begining there will be a counter for this here you need OPD card and aadhar and some cash to make the file after that for operation they will shift you to the next building i.e Trauma and emergency care

For the free check up like blood xray etc etc you need to visit Room 2nd floor  201 A (Trauma Buliding) to make a Ayushman Bharat / arogya karnataka approval for this you need to have a ration card with aadhar and a photo of the patient with the doctor. Once you get the approval then everything will be free. After that you need to visit the doctor and list down the test needed and in entrance there will be a reception which is too crowded there you have to get the slips for the particular tests once everything is done

1.Blood Test : you need to bring the sample test tube From the first floor and the respective doctor will collect the sample and need to submit to the blood testing department it may take 1-2 hrs for the blood report

2. X Ray : It will be done in 1 St floor it's self where it will be too crowded and need to wait for 1-2 hrs for this report also

3. ECG : It will be done in the ground floor emergency sector itself

The hospital here is very well maintained it like a private hospital very clean and very well specialised with modern equipment and good doctors

Most of the doctors are students who will be treated in a good manner and very well behaved.

But here the major draw backs are the cleaning department people and the nursing staff these peoples are hectic who keeps on asking money like anything minimum amount should be 100-500 they will do there work but we have to pay like a bribe to them they will demand for the money like they own the Hospital.
If you give them money means they will treat you like God or else they will treat you like dog where they will show this grudge on patient while you are not there.
The staff attitude is like they are doctor with double degree.
There are the reason for the 3 star
Every hospital is located one beside the other namely
Minto
Trauma and emergency care
Vani villas etc

But the Victoria hospital main building is one of the worst buildings compared to Trauma the beds and ward are old and their staff are the worst where their attitude and asking for money is one the main roles for them.

During the discharge you need to again visit the 201 A ayushman/arogya karnataka approval with the previous approved documents and the file form the doctor and the photo of the patient with the doctor and the operated area photo(wound). Once the approval is done you're good to go with the discharge procedure.

The one thing is for sure If you have good money and influence this the place where everything will happen smoothly and quickly

It is one of the most renowned institutes in the country, so I expected it to be the same but somewhat I am not impressed by it. Many institutes have left its level and are years forward then it, the government should let it's unnecessary free schemes go and focus on what really matters.

Came with head injury afternoon very bad experience no proper doctor given drips and took ct scan done stitches but neurologist doctor is not available and no police complaint was done hopeless i request people not to go their government hospital should take care of a patient with Good manner with good respect , cleanliness is not their no proper bed no proper house keeping . And first of all doctors don't know how to treat a patient they are treating patients like dog and cows illiterate doctors and no nurses in Victoria Hospital. Very irresponsible behaviour with doctors. They look money first not the patient they took long time treat a me. No doctors are active all are lazy doctors how they are getting doctor seats and how they are becoming doctors.once again I ask people not to visit vicotria hospital save your own life below is the doctor picture who attended to me only cheap mentality and cheap behaviour he has he doesn't have dignity and he is not fit to be a doctor theirs no professional doctors all are rowdies in that hospital when you given money they will treat you in a very good manner or else they won't, when I went to complain about the doctor to the chief Medical Administration he is also useless and he is supporting doctor who are doing wrong.kindly i request to share this feedback Even in face book and instagram and every were. Very bad and cheapest behaviour of doctors and chief Medical Administration persons one men and women

To Whom It May Concern,
It is truly disheartening to witness the lack of basic courtesy and professionalism from the hospital staff, including doctors, nurses, cleaning staff, and administrative personnel. Many of them speak rudely, show no empathy towards patients or their families, and often behave in an unhelpful manner. Even in critical situations, there appears to be a shocking lack of urgency and concern for the well-being of patients.
One particularly upsetting experience involved the staff at the admission counter. The lady there was extremely disrespectful, speaking rudely even to senior citizens. Additionally, the hospital lacks basic modern facilities such as digital payment options, forcing people to rely solely on cash—even in emergencies.
Patients who are already in distress are made to run from one room to another, instead of being provided with immediate care. This lack of coordination and compassion is unacceptable.
I urge the concerned authorities and the hospital management to take immediate steps to improve the behavior and professionalism of the staff. Basic training in communication, empathy, and patient care is urgently needed. Staff members must learn to speak politely, treat people with respect, and keep their tone calm and composed.
The current state of affairs is deeply concerning, and I hope this issue is taken seriously before more lives are impacted due to negligence and lack of proper conduct.

I went for a orthopedic treatment. The doctor was really good. Amidst all the crowd, he patiently listened to our problem and provided good treatment. He also suggested a physiotherapy treatment , which was right next door. The physiotherapist was too good. She too did what was needed.
Parking is a problem though. Also keep in mind that this is a govt hospital. There is going to be long queues and huge waiting time in some cases. Kindly keep that in mind. They are trying to provide the best of the services they can.

placeMetadata.name: University of Visvesvaraya College of Engineering Electrical Department

sources.snippet: Started by Sir M. Visvesvaraya, this was the first engineering college to be established in the erstwhile Mysore State, and only the fifth in all of India. Its first batch of students, in 1917, had only twenty students. placeMetadata.name: Shri Nandi Swami Temple (Big Bull Mandir)

sources.snippet: Big Bull Temple is the biggest and one of the oldest temples in India dedicated to sacred bull Nandi, a devotee of Lord Shiva. An enormous statue carved out on a single granite rock is a spectacular work of art. The imposing statue of the bull is 6 m long and has a height of 4.5 m.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Historical Places in Bangalore

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Shri Nandi Swami Temple, also known as Big Bull Mandir, is a famous religious site located in India. The temple is dedicated to Nandi, the sacred bull and vehicle of Lord Shiva. It is adorned with intricate carvings and sculptures, making it a visually stunning attraction for visitors. The temple holds great significance for devotees and offers a peaceful atmosphere for spiritual reflection.
placeMetadata.address: Bull Temple, Steps to Bull Temple, Basavanagudi, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560004, India

reviews.reviewText: A very sacred place and peaceful......It is just beside the Dooda Ganesha Temple.....Located at Baswangudi......Nearby Metro is Lalbagh or National College any one you can choose and just 1.75 kms approx from both the Metro.....20 minutes walking distance.
My lovely place in Bangalore ❤️🙏🙂

Shri Nandi Swami Temple is a serene and spiritually uplifting destination, located atop a picturesque hill. The temple is dedicated to Nandi, the sacred bull of Lord Shiva, and features a massive Nandi sculpture carved from a single rock, showcasing exquisite craftsmanship and deep historical significance.

Experience & Surroundings:
- The climb up to the temple is refreshing, surrounded by lush greenery and a peaceful atmosphere. It’s an ideal spot for those looking to escape the chaos of the city and immerse themselves in nature and spirituality.
- The ambience is calm and relaxing, making it perfect for meditation or simply unwinding in the presence of divinity.

Sri Dodda Ganapathi Temple:
At the foot of the hill, you will find Sri Dodda Ganapathi Temple, another must-visit shrine. It is known for its massive Ganapathi idol, which is said to bring prosperity and blessings to devotees.

Final Thoughts:
Whether you are a devotee, nature lover, or history enthusiast, Shri Nandi Swami Temple offers a blend of spirituality, scenic beauty, and peace. A visit here is not just about seeking blessings but also about experiencing tranquility and cultural richness.

The Bull Temple (Dodda Basavana Gudi) in Basavanagudi, Bengaluru, is a remarkable blend of spiritual heritage and architectural grandeur.The temple is dedicated to Nandi, the sacred bull and vahana (vehicle) of Lord Shiva. Its most striking feature is the massive monolithic statue of Nandi.

An annual highlight is the Kadalekai Parishe (Groundnut Fair), held in November or December, where farmers offer their first groundnut harvest to Nandi as a gesture of gratitude. The temple premises come alive with stalls selling various groundnut-based products, creating a festive atmosphere.
You can also visit nearby Bugle Rock Garden, known for its natural rock formations and serene environment. The Bull Temple offers a peaceful retreat from the city's hustle and bustle, making it a must-visit for both devotees and tourists.​

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we’re always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Bengaluru, often celebrated for its vibrant tech scene, is also a treasure trove of architectural wonders that reflect its rich history and cultural diversity. From the grand Vidhana Soudha, a stunning example of neo-Dravidian architecture, to the charming Sheshadri Iyer Memorial Hall nestled on the edge of Cubbon Park, the city offers a captivating blend of old and new. Each structure tells a story, whether it's the opulent Tipu Sultan's Summer Palace or the striking Gothic lines of St. Mary's Basilica, inviting visitors to explore the layers of Bengaluru's past.

As you wander through the city, you'll encounter a mix of majestic palaces, historic libraries, and modern marvels that showcase the creativity and craftsmanship of different eras. The Bangalore Palace, with its fortified towers and lush gardens, stands as a testament to royal heritage, while the National Gallery of Modern Art offers a glimpse into contemporary artistic expressions. Whether you're an architecture enthusiast or simply curious about the city's charm, Bengaluru's architectural landscape promises to inspire and delight. So, lace up your walking shoes and get ready to discover the stunning structures that define this dynamic city!
